item.title: A Flawed Encryption Policy
item.description: Authors: Anonymous Published: April 1996 URL: https://search.proquest.com/docview/430685501/fulltext/2EA1B6B49BC74036PQ/1?accountid=14503 Tags: 1990s Clinton Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Export Controls Terrorism Abstract: An editorial contends that the new White House proposal to keep high-powered encryption software out of the hands of foreign terrorists and criminals is needlessly restrictive and probably unworkable. The editorial says that the technology, which is legal in the US, is a good way for honest citizens to prevent crime and should be disseminated domestically and abroad.

item.description: Authors: Madsen, Wayne Published: July 1997 URL: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1361372397895486 Tags: 1990s Clinton Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Export Controls Key Recovery Abstract: “Are those in opposition to the administration’s [encryption] policy prepared to sacrifice public safety in the interests of commercial gain?” Those words, uttered by Deputy Assistant Attorney General Robert Litt, would etch themselves in the minds of those who attended the 7 May 1977 House International Economic Policy and Trade hearing on “Encryption: Individual Rights vs National Security”.

item.title: Encryption: A 21st Century National Security Dilemma
item.description: Authors: Ackerman, Wystan M. Published: July 1998 URL: https://doi.org/10.1080/13600869855487 Tags: 1990s Clinton Export Controls Law Enforcement Abstract: As the 21st century approaches, encryption is presenting a national security dilemma in the US. While the use of strong encryption for computerized data is essential in protecting our nation, widespread, unregulated encryption poses serious problems on two levels: encryption could inhibit the government’s ability to enforce the law as well as gather foreign intelligence.

item.title: US Encryption Export Regualtion: US to EU: Me Too! — The United States Amends Its Export Controls on Encrption, Responding to Recent Developments in the European Union
item.description: Authors: Thomsen II, Roszel C and Paytas, Antoinette D Published: January 2001 URL: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0267364901001030 Tags: 2000s Export Controls Law Enforcement Abstract: This paper reviews the most recent changes to the US export controls on encryption items (referred to herein as the “US Regulations”) that were published in the US Federal Register on 19 October, 2000.1165 Fed. Reg. 62600 (2000). It describes how the decision by the European Union (EU) Council of Ministers on 22 June 2000, to create a license free zone for exports of encryption (and other) items (referred to herein as the “EU Regulations”) provided the initial stimulus for these changes.
